channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: In Phone Call, Biden Warns Putin of ‘Severe’ Costs of Invading Ukraine
item.description: The call came hours after the State Department ordered all but a “core team” of American diplomats to leave the embassy in Kyiv amid concerns of an imminent Russian attack.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier at a front-line position in Pisky, eastern Ukraine, this week.

item.title: Black Authors Shake Up Brazil’s Literary Scene
item.description: Young Black Brazilians are publishing on their own terms, achieving the critical and commercial success that eluded past generations of writers from marginalized communities.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Itamar Vieira Júnior, an author, says a major reason Black Brazilian writers are making their mark is because of a shift in how race and racism are being discussed in the country today.

item.title: Canada Live Updates: Most Protesters Leave Ontario Bridge, but Traffic Is Still Blocked
item.description: Some truckers are stopping the flow of traffic across the Ambassador Bridge, a critical juncture along Canada’s border with the United States.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Canadian police deploy to move protesters blocking access to the Ambassador Bridge in Windsor, Ontario Canada, Saturday morning.

item.title: Emmanuel Macron Recounts Face-Off With Vladimir Putin
item.description: The French leader recounted his face-off with Vladimir Putin and dismissed Washington’s exchange of letters with Moscow, gambling that his diplomacy could pay off before April elections.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France said he was searching for a new “framework” for European security.

item.title: How a Chechen Abduction Exposes Putin’s Problems at Home
item.description: A furor over the arrest of a woman by agents of the Chechen strongman Ramzan Kadyrov shows the internal challenges facing President Vladimir V. Putin, even as he tries to project global power.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Election posters featuring the Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov on the outskirts of Grozny in September. Mr. Kadyrov exerts almost total control in Chechnya.

item.title: Switzerland, Long a Safe Haven for Tobacco Ads, Weighs a Ban
item.description: Voters will decide Sunday on whether to prohibit the ads in places where they can be seen by children under 18.
item.dc:creator: Noele Illien
item.media:description: A billboard in Lausanne, Switzerland, this week reads: “Children without tobacco, YES.”

item.title: Blinken Says U.S. Has a ‘Long-Term Future’ in the Pacific Islands
item.description: The secretary of state promised a new embassy in the Solomon Islands and help on issues like climate change, as Washington vies with Beijing for influence in the region.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Damien Cave
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken with Fiji’s acting prime minister, Aiyaz Sayed-Khaiyum, right, as he arrived in the country on Saturday.

item.title: Canada Toughens Stance on Protests, Promising ‘Robust’ Police Response
item.description: After treading lightly for weeks, officials obtained a court order to halt the blockade of a major route to the United States. They also vowed fines and arrests.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Ottawa on Friday.

item.title: Taliban Free 2 Westerners Working for U.N., Days After Quiet Detention
item.description: The issue of detentions and disappearances has put a new spotlight on the Taliban’s promises to improve their human rights record under the weight of international sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Taliban fighter guarding a United Nations aid distribution site in Kabul, Afghanistan, in October.

item.title: White House Warns Russian Invasion of Ukraine Could Happen at Any Time
item.description: A host of countries, including the United States, has told their citizens to leave Ukraine immediately.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers and Andrew E. Kramer
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Photo by Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier at a front-line position in Pisky, eastern Ukraine, this week.

item.title: No Hijabs for Now, Indian Court Tells Muslim Students
item.description: In a dispute that’s become a flash point over minority rights, students are told to avoid religious garments of all kinds, pending a ruling on whether schools can ban head scarves.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj and Emily Schmall
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Muslim women demonstrating in Bangalore, in the Indian state of Karnataka, on Monday.

item.title: French Demonstrators Converge on Paris, Inspired by Canadian Trucker Protests
item.description: The police have deployed over 7,000 officers around the city and have already issued a ban against the convoy.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: A protester holding a French flag and a sign reading ‘Freedom convoy’ at Place Denfert-Rochereau in southern Paris on Friday evening.

item.title: She Had Never Acted, and Could Barely Read. Now, She’s an Egyptian Movie Star.
item.description: A stay-at-home mother deprived of an education, Damiana Nassar played a woman much like herself in “Feathers,” a Cannes winner that few in Egypt can see.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee

item.title: Nathan Crumpton Became an Olympic Sensation, Without a Shirt and Without Competing
item.description: A flag-bearer for American Samoa lit up the internet when he appeared at the opening ceremony in Beijing wearing very little clothing in subfreezing weather.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nathan Ikon Crumpton in a practice run earlier this week in Yanqing, China. He is competing in skeleton for American Samoa.

item.title: 'Lunana,' a Movie From Bhutan, Is Nominated for an Academy Award
item.description: “Lunana: A Yak in the Classroom” was filmed on a shoestring budget in a remote Himalayan village. It’s now an Academy Award nominee, a first for Bhutan.
item.dc:creator: Chencho Dema and Mike Ives
item.category: Lunana: A Yak in the Classroom (Movie)

item.title: As Violence Rises in the West Bank, Settler Attacks Raise Alarm
item.description: Attacks by settlers and Palestinians have both reached a five-year high. But unlike Palestinian suspects, violent settlers are rarely prosecuted.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinian farmers harvesting olives last fall under the eye of Israeli soldiers. Some farmers are afraid to tend their groves without military protection.

item.title: U.S. Battles Putin by Disclosing His Next Possible Moves
item.description: Declassified information is part of a campaign to complicate what officials say are Russia’s plans to invade Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Helene Cooper
item.media:description: The United States hopes that disclosing the plans of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia regarding Ukraine will disrupt them, perhaps delaying an invasion and buying more time for diplomacy.

item.title: In Ottawa Protests, a Pressing Question: Where Were the Police?
item.description: They were vastly outnumbered, experts say, and unprepared for the sophisticated tactics, discipline and logistical abilities of the protesters.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers walking through trucks blocking the streets in Ottawa on Friday. They were often swarmed when trying to make arrests.

item.title: Sleeping in Pieces
item.description: Are sleep disruptions here to stay?
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Walmart Says Vaccinated Workers No Longer Have to Wear Masks
item.description: The retailer said it was taking action after governors from Connecticut to California ended mask mandates recently.
item.dc:creator: Lauren McCarthy
item.media:description: Ringing up a customer’s purchases at a Walmart store in North Brunswick, N.J., in 2020.

item.title: Scientists prepare for the next phase of learning to live with Covid.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Masks, vaccines and paid sick leave may allow the pandemic to enter a new phase with fewer restrictions, some scientists say.

item.title: Puzzle in Ukraine Crisis: Where’s the U.S. Ambassador?
item.description: Diplomats say President Biden’s 13-month delay in sending an envoy to a top crisis spot is impossible to explain.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
item.media:description: The U.S. Embassy building in Kyiv. The unfilled ambassadorship is a particularly freighted topic, coming as a reminder of one of the biggest scandals of the last presidency.

item.title: To Frustration of Many, Trudeau Has Moved Slowly With Canada Protests
item.description: Amid calls for a harder federal line against the truck blockade, the prime minister’s restraint so far has kept it from becoming a referendum on his leadership.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dana-Lee Melfi standing in front of trucks blocking streets in downtown Ottawa on Friday.

item.title: U.S. to Send 3,000 More Troops to Poland Amid Russia-Ukraine Crisis
item.description: The Biden administration has ruled out sending U.S. troops to defend Ukraine, but has increased deployments to NATO countries in Eastern Europe that are wary of Russia.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers in Ft. Bragg, N.C., prepare to deploy to Eastern Europe earlier this month.

item.title: The F.D.A. delays action on Covid shots for young children.
item.description: In a striking reversal, federal regulators said that they would wait for data on whether three doses of Pfizer-BioNTech’s vaccine are effective in children younger than 5.
item.dc:creator: Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland
item.media:credit: Emily Elconin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fiona Backes, 5, with her mother after receiving her first coronavirus vaccine dose in Michigan last year. The F.D.A. authorized the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine for children 5 to 11 in October.

item.title: Brooklyn's Poly Prep Reverses Plan to Make Masks Optional
item.description: Poly Prep Country Day School had been the first school in New York City to make masks optional. A spokeswoman for the state’s Department of Health had called the decision a “violation.”
item.dc:creator: Precious Fondren
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.media:description: One of the campuses of Poly Prep Country Day School, in Dyker Heights, Brooklyn.

item.title: Canada Border Blockades Leave Automakers Scrambling
item.description: Some companies are trying to use U.S.-Canada crossings hundreds of miles from the bridges that protesters have blocked.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Elaine Cromie for The New York Times
item.media:description: A closed ramp to the Ambassador Bridge, which connects Detroit and Windsor, Ontario, on Thursday.

item.title: Ukrainian Athlete Protests During His Skeleton Competition
item.description: Vladyslav Heraskevych held up a sign that said “no war in Ukraine.” It is unclear whether the I.O.C. will penalize him for making a statement during an event.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri
item.media:description: Vladyslav Heraskevych, Ukraine’s lone skeleton racer, displayed a sign that read “no war in Ukraine” after a run on Friday.

item.title: U.S. intelligence says Putin has accelerated his timetable and could invade within days.
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said at a news conference in Melbourne on Friday that a Russian invasion could even occur before the Winter Olympics in Beijing end on Feb. 20.
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Joe Biden and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz at the White House this week.

item.title: Where Is All the Bing Dwen Dwen Memorabilia in China?
item.description: Olympics memorabilia has become an unexpected hit in China, and none more so than a plush stuffed panda that is the mascot of the Beijing Games.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher

item.title: Why 'Following the Science' To Minimize Covid Risk May Not Be So Easy
item.description: If only it were so easy.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Wearing masks in New York City.

item.title: Shining a Spotlight on the Art of Translation
item.description: Jennifer Croft, who translates the Nobel Prize-winning Polish novelist Olga Tokarczuk, is leading a push for her peers and their work to receive more recognition.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter
item.media:credit: Magdalena Wosinska for The New York Times
item.media:description: The translator Jennifer Croft will no longer work with publishers who don’t put her name on the cover. Readers “should know who chose the words they’re going to read,” she says.

item.title: Australia Declares Koalas an Endangered Species
item.description: Years of drought, fires and habitat loss have drastically reduced the population of the iconic marsupial.
item.dc:creator: Manan Luthra

item.title: Biden Moves to Split $7 Billion in Frozen Afghan Funds
item.description: The president intends to use the Afghan central bank’s assets to fund needs in Afghanistan amid a humanitarian disaster, and compensate victims of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers in Kabul measuring out food for Afghans to receive from the World Food Program. Mass starvation has gripped much of the country since the Taliban took control.

item.title: Readers Reflect on the State of Australian Politics
item.description: Some thoughts on a better politics — and some relief Australia isn’t America.
item.dc:creator: Besha Rodell
item.media:description: Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia.

item.title: As Other Hot Spots Boil, U.S. Shows Its Foreign Policy Focus Is Asia
item.description: Antony Blinken’s Asia-Pacific trip during the crisis with Russia and Ukraine signals that the U.S. is committing to the world’s largest region — and to competition with China.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: From left, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, the Australian foreign minister, Marise Payne, Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia, the Indian foreign minister, Subrahmanyam Jaishankar, and the Japanese foreign minister, Yoshimasa Hayashi, in Melbourne, Australia, on Friday.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Russia closes in on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier in Donetsk, Ukraine.

item.title: The Slippery Science of Skeleton
item.description: Researchers are still figuring out how to enable athletes in the face-first Olympic sled race to go even faster.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Imbler
item.media:description: Matt Weston of Great Britain running at the start of a skeleton run at the Yanqing National Sliding Center in Beijing on Wednesday.

item.title: What to Know About the Canada Trucker Protests
item.description: Once narrowly focused on a vaccine mandate for drivers entering Canada from the U.S., the protests have ballooned into a sprawling campaign against various grievances.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah
item.media:description: Hundreds of truck drivers and their supporters blocked the streets of downtown Ottawa on Thursday, part of a dayslong protest against public health measures.

item.title: US Military Offers New Details on Raid That Led to Death of ISIS Leader
item.description: A tip from informants helped set in motion a commando raid that led to the death of the elusive terrorist, Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurayshi, in Syria last week.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Ben Hubbard
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Anas Alkharboutli/picture alliance via Getty Images
item.media:description: The damaged house where Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurashi died during a raid by U.S. commandos in northwestern Syria last week.

item.title: Russia Massing More Troops Near Ukraine, Satellite Images Show
item.description: The Russian buildup includes more forces in Crimea, western Russia and Belarus, adding to fears that Russia could invade Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Christoph Koettl

item.title: Libya Slides Deeper Into Chaos as Parliament Picks New Government
item.description: The current prime minister, Abdul Hamid Dbeiba, rejected Parliament’s decision, raising concerns that the oil-rich African nation was returning to a divide with two rival governments.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Mohammed Abdusamee
item.media:description: The Libyan Parliament in session in the eastern city of Tobruk on Thursday.

item.title: Armed Nationalists in Ukraine Pose a Threat Not Just to Russia
item.description: Kyiv is encouraging the arming of nationalist paramilitary groups to thwart a Russian invasion. But they could also destabilize the government if it agrees to a peace deal they reject.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yuri Hudymenko, head of the Democratic Ax party, in the group’s offices on Thursday in Kyiv.

item.title: With Buildup on Land and Sea, Russia Closes in on Ukraine
item.description: Military drills in Belarus, deployments in western Russia and Crimea, and planned naval exercises in the Black Sea gave an ominous undertone to a continuing diplomatic scramble.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops at front line position in Donetsk, Ukraine.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Russia’s Large-Scale Military Drills
item.description: Troops along the Ukraine border bring unease.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Russian Defense Ministry, via Agence France-Presse - Getty Images
item.media:description: Joint military exercises between Russia and Belarus in Brest, Belarus.

item.title: Cressida Dick Resigns as London Police Commissioner
item.description: The commissioner, Cressida Dick, announced her resignation under pressure from the mayor over reports of bullying, misogyny and racism on the force.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Cressida Dick, the Metropolitan Police Commissioner, announced on Thursday that she would be stepping down as the leader of London’s Metropolitan Police.

item.title: Marie-Claire Chevalier, Catalyst for French Abortion Law, Dies at 66
item.description: While in high school in 1972, she was raped and became pregnant. Her illegal abortion paved the way for France to decriminalize the procedure in 1975.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Q. Seelye and Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Marie-Claire Chevalier, fourth from left, exited a French courthouse in November 1972 after she was acquitted of having an illegal abortion. With her are, from left, her lawyers Monique Antoine and Gisèle Halimi and her mother Michèle Chevalier.

item.title: England Urges Farmers to Make Peace With Hikers
item.description: In a country where public access to parts of the countryside is written into law, the government gave landowners some advice. But farmers say they are not the problem.
item.dc:creator: Aina J. Khan
item.media:description: Walking along a public footpath and through fields in Sevenoaks, England, in 2020.

item.title: France Announces a Big Buildup of Its Nuclear Power Program
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron outlined plans for a wave of new-generation atomic reactors as the country seeks to slash planet-warming emissions.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman
item.media:credit: Jean-Francois Badias/Agence France-Presse, via Pool/Afp Via Getty Images
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France speaking at a turbine factory on Thursday. “The time has come for a nuclear renaissance,” he said.
